description: From Middle English *dosen, from Old Norse dúsa (“to doze, rest, remain quiet”), from Proto-Germanic *dusāną (“to be dizzy”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰews- (“to fly, whirl”), from *dʰew- (“to fly, shake, reek, steam, smolder”).

Cognate with Old Frisian dusia (“to be dizzy”), German Low German dösen (“to doze”), German dösen (“to doze”), Danish døse (“to doze”), dialectal Swedish dusa (“to doze, slumber”), Icelandic dúsa (“to doze”), Old English dysiġ (“foolish, stupid”), Scots dosnit (“stunned, stupefied”), Icelandic dúra (“to nap, slumber”), also compare Dutch doezelen (“to doze”). More at dizzy.

entries.meaning: A light, short sleep or nap.
examples: I felt much better after a short doze.

verbs.description: doze (third-person singular simple present dozes, present participle dozing, simple past and past participle dozed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To sleep lightly or briefly; to nap, snooze.
examples: I didn’t sleep very well, but I think I may have dozed a bit.
I was an hour  […]  in casting up about twenty sums, being dozed with much work.
